Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Kr-86 as a Proxy for Barometric Pressure Variability and Movement of the SH Westerlies during the last Deglaciation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Brook 1543267

Approximately half of the human caused carbon dioxide emissions to the atmosphere are absorbed by the ocean, which reduces the amount of global warming associated with these emissions. Much of this carbon uptake occurs in the Southern Ocean around Antarctica, where water from the deep ocean comes to the surface. How much water "up-wells," and therefore how much carbon is absorbed, is believed to depend on the strength and location of the major westerly winds in the southern hemisphere. These wind patterns have been shifting southward in recent decades, and future changes could impact the global carbon cycle and promote the circulation of relatively warm water from the deep ocean on to the continental shelf, which contributes to enhanced Antarctic ice melt and sea level rise. Understanding of the westerly winds and their role in controlling atmospheric carbon dioxide levels and the circulation of ocean water is therefore very important. The work supported by this award will study past movement of the SH westerlies in response to natural climate variations. Of particular interest is the last deglaciation (20,000 to 10,000 years ago), when the global climate made a transition from an ice age climate to the current warm period. During this period, atmospheric carbon dioxide rose from about 180 ppm to 270 parts per million, and one leading hypothesis is that the rise in carbon dioxide was driven by a southward movement of the southern hemisphere westerlies. The broader impacts of the work include a perspective on past movement of the southern hemisphere westerlies and their link to atmospheric carbon dioxide, which could guide projections of future oceanic carbon dioxide uptake, with strong societal benefits; international collaboration with German scientists; training of a postdoctoral investigator; and outreach to public schools.

This project will investigate whether the abundance of a noble gas, krypton-86, trapped in Antarctic ice cores, records atmospheric pressure variability, and whether or not this pressure variability can be used to infer past movement of the Southern Hemisphere westerly winds. The rationale for the project is that models of air movement in the snow pack (firn) in Antarctica indicate that pressure variations drive air movement that disturbs the normal enrichment in krypton-86 caused by gravitational settling of gases. Calculations predict that the krypton-86 deviation from gravitational equilibrium reflects the magnitude of pressure variations. In turn, atmospheric data show that pressure variability over Antarctica is linked to the position of the southern hemisphere westerly winds. Preliminary data from the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Divide ice core show a large excursion in krypton-86 during the transition from the last ice age to the current warm period. The investigators will perform krypton-86 analysis on ice core and firn air samples to establish whether the Kr-86 deviation is linked to pressure variability, refine the record of krypton isotopes from the WAIS Divide ice core, investigate the role of pressure variability in firn air transport using firn air models, and investigate how barometric pressure variability in Antarctica is linked to the position/strength of the SH westerlies in past and present climates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our atmosphere is an important component of the climate system. Atmospheric circulation (winds) transports moisture and energy across the planet, which determines global rainfall and temperature patterns. Atmospheric wind patterns change through time and with climate, and understanding such changes is important for societies as they need to adapt. Wind changes are typically organized into large global patterns (or modes), of which the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is the most famous example. Another example is the Southern Annular Mode, which dominates wind patterns in the Southern Hemisphere mid- and high-latitudes.  

Past climates, such as the last ice age (120,000 to 18,000 years ago), were very different from our current climate and provide a natural laboratory for studying the behavior of these atmospheric modes under a wide range of conditions. This helps scientists understand their dynamics, making it possible to make more informed projections of future changes. The project developed a new proxy method (called Kr-86 excess) for reconstructing past atmospheric circulation change using ice cores from the polar regions (Greenland and Antarctica). The method is based on measuring the stable isotope ratios of the noble gases argon and krypton in ice cores. Gas bubbles are trapped at the bottom of the 60-120 m thick firn layer (perennial snow pack). Within this firn layer the heavier isotopes settle to the bottom (where the bubbles close off), and therefore ice core samples are enriched in the heavy noble gas isotopes. Storm systems passing through the ice core site disturb this gravitational settling effect, which can be detected by measuring the argon and krypton isotopes.

Intellectual merit: The project performed an Antarctic-wide calibration study using samples from 11 ice cores to figure out whether the Kr-86 excess proxy method works, and found strong evidence that the method indeed works as proposed. The project further performed various 1-D and 2-D modeling studies to better understand air movement in the firn layer, and to provide a theoretical basis for Kr-86 excess. The project studied modern-day air movement from observational data, and found that past El Niño and Southern Annular Mode dynamics can in principle be reconstructed by studying ice cores from different sectors of Antarctica. Last, using a record of Kr-86 excess from the WAIS Divide ice core that spans the last 23,000 years, the project provides evidence for past movement of the southern hemisphere mid-latitude jet stream position over the Pacific. The project opens up new avenues for investigating past atmospheric dynamics, with benefits to paleoclimate and atmospheric research. 

Broader impacts: The Southern Annular Mode influences the oceanic uptake of atmospheric carbon dioxide from fossil fuel combustion, which determines the amount that stays in our atmosphere where it contributes to climate warming. Understanding the dynamics of this atmospheric pattern is important for understanding future climate. The project provided support for a postdoctoral scholar (who transitioned to a faculty position during the award period) and a graduate student, thereby contributing to the STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) workforce. During the project duration, team members visited multiple middle schools in the Corvallis area annually to provide a day of polar research education. This outreach effort reached around 400-600 middle school students annually, engaging a young generation into the scientific method.
